question: Oxfam Charity Shop Overwhelmed with Donations of "The Da Vinci Code" and Begs for Vinyl Records Instead
summary: – the da vinci code has sold so many copies — that would be at least 80 million — that it ' s bound to turn up in book donation piles . but at one charity shop in the uk , it ' s been donated so heavily that the shop has posted a sign propped up on a tower of da vinci code copies that reads : " you could give us another da vinci code ... but we would rather have your vinyl ! " the manager of the oxfam shop in swansea tells the telegraph that people are laughing and taking pictures of the sizable display : " i would say that we get one copy of the book every day . " he says people buy them " occasionally , " but with vinyl sales up 25 % in the past year , they ' d rather take records . dan brown ' s book isn ' t the only one that shops like oxfam struggle to re-sell . last year , oxfam was hit with a large and steady supply of fifty shades of grey , and it similarly begged donors : " please — no more . " but brown has a particular kind of staying power . the da vinci code was published in 2003 , and within six years brown had booted john grisham from the no . 1 slot on the list of writers whose books were most often donated to oxfam ' s 700 shops , reported the guardian at the time . the independent in 2012 reported brown ' s best-seller was the most-donated book for the fourth year running . ( see why dan brown took heat from the philippines. )

summary: – yemen-based al-qaeda in the arabian peninsula has claimed responsibility for the charlie hebdo attack in an online video called " vengeance for the prophet : a message regarding the blessed battle of paris , " the new york times reports . the group says it " chose the target , laid the plan , and financed the operation " in " a vengeance for the messenger of allah " — a likely reference to charlie hebdo ' s parodies of the prophet muhammad . but while aqap called the kouachi brothers " two heroes of islam , " it suggests it wasn ' t behind the attacks that followed , including on a kosher supermarket . gunman amedy coulibaly ' s actions were a coincidence , the statement says , calling him simply a " mujahid brother . " the charlie hebdo attackers claimed to be working for aqap , while coulibaly has pledged support for isis , the bbc notes . the statement , made by aqap leader nasser bin ali al-ansi , says the attack was an " implementation " of orders from ayman al-zawahiri , the leader of the larger al-qaeda group , reuters reports . the video also featured an image of the eiffel tower dissolving , the times reports . meanwhile , today ' s issue of charlie hebdo sold out in minutes .

Title: AQAP claims responsibility for Charlie Hebdo attack, denies involvement in subsequent attacks

Introduction:
modelText:
The attack on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo on January 7, 2015, was a tragic event that left 12 people dead and many more injured. The attack was carried out by two brothers, Said and Cherif Kouachi, who were later killed by police. The attack was widely condemned by governments and human rights organizations around the world, and it sparked a global debate about freedom of speech and the limits of tolerance.

In the aftermath of the attack, the al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) terrorist group claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that it was in retaliation for the magazine's depiction of the Prophet Muhammad. However, AQAP has since denied any involvement in subsequent attacks that have taken place in France, including the November 2015 attacks in Paris that killed 130 people.

This introduction provides a brief overview of the Charlie Hebdo attack and the subsequent claims and denials made by AQAP. It sets the stage for a more in-depth exploration of the topic, including the motivations behind the attack, the response of governments and human rights organizations, and the ongoing debate about freedom of speech and tolerance.

" click for the full piece .

Title: The New York Times Investigation: Inside the NSA's Surveillance Operations

modelText:
The New York Times has recently published an investigation into the National Security Agency's (NSA) surveillance operations, providing a rare glimpse into the agency's inner workings and the extent of its powers. The investigation, based on interviews with current and former NSA officials, reveals the agency's use of advanced technologies and techniques to collect and analyze vast amounts of data, both domestically and abroad. Key Findings:

1. The NSA has been using advanced technologies, such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, to automate the process of collecting and analyzing data. These technologies allow the agency to sift through vast amounts of data in real-time, identifying patterns and anomalies that may be of interest to intelligence analysts.
2. The NSA has been collecting data not only from foreign governments and organizations, but also from American companies and individuals. This includes data from social media, email, and other online communications, as well as data from financial transactions and other digital activities.
3. The agency has been using a network of secret facilities and partnerships around the world to collect and analyze data. These facilities, known as "listening posts," are located in countries such as Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom, and are used to intercept and process data from satellite communications, internet traffic, and other sources.
4. The NSA has been working closely with other intelligence agencies, such as the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), to gather and analyze data. These agencies have been sharing information and resources, and have been collaborating on operations and investigations.

( this man followed a hunch , says he uncovered a lost city. )

Title: "Archaeologist Uncovers Lost City of Etzanoa in Kansas, Challenging Historical Confusion"

Introduction:
modelText:
Etzanoa, a lost city believed to have existed in the 16th century, has long been a subject of fascination and confusion among historians and archaeologists. Despite its significance in the history of the American Southwest, the location of the city has remained a mystery for centuries. However, recent discoveries by archaeologists have shed new light on the whereabouts of Etzanoa, challenging the historical confusion and providing a more accurate understanding of the city's existence.

In this introduction, we will explore the history of Etzanoa, the challenges of locating the lost city, and the recent discoveries that have helped to clarify its location. We will also examine the significance of these findings and their impact on our understanding of the history of the American Southwest.

" in the journal clinical anatomy , researchers write that others have previously suggested a link between androgen exposure in the womb and schizophrenia ; they take that one step further , hypothesizing the ratio could be predictive of schizophrenia in males . then they set out to test that hypothesis : in their small study , researchers analyzed the finger lengths of 103 turkish male patients diagnosed with schizophrenia and 100 healthy male controls . they found " significant differences between schizophrenia and control groups concerning the ratio ... in both hands , " the researchers report in a press release . the findings occupy opposite ends of the spectrum : the right-hand 2d : 4d ratio was " significantly higher " among the schizophrenia group and the left-hand ratio was " significantly lower " — suggesting the two are opposites , perhaps because testosterone " affects finger ratios differently as it acts in different ways on the left and right hemispheres of the brain , " per the study . as for those ratios , the researchers found the size of the ratio in the left hand could indicate the severity of negative symptoms in patients . This ratio has previously been linked to prenatal androgen exposure, which is known to play a role in the development of schizophrenia.

The study's findings suggest that measuring finger length ratios may be a useful tool for identifying individuals at risk of developing schizophrenia. However, it is important to note that this is not a definitive diagnostic test, and other factors such as family history, cognitive function, and brain imaging should also be considered when assessing schizophrenia risk.

* Cornstarch: Used as a binder, cornstarch helps to hold the nugget together and prevent it from falling apart during cooking.
* Salt and pepper: Used to enhance flavor and preserve the nugget.

Republicans have been vocal in their opposition to these procedures, calling them invasive and infringing on personal liberties.

In addition to the TSA, Republicans have also been critical of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START) between the United States and Russia. The treaty aims to reduce the number of nuclear weapons in each country's arsenal, but Republicans have argued that it favors Russia and does not do enough to address the threat of nuclear proliferation.

Despite these issues, Republicans have prioritized undermining President Obama's policies and agenda, rather than working to address the concerns of the American people. summary: – a one-of-a-kind dime minted in 1873 sold for $ 1.6 million at a philadelphia auction last night , reports ap . the coin depicts a seated lady liberty , and it is thought to be the lone survivor from a one-day minting of dimes at the renowned ( in coin circles , anyway ) mint in carson city , nevada . another 110 coins also went up for auction , one of each coin minted in carson city before its facility closed in 1893. total haul : $ 10 million . total face value of the coins : about $ 600 , according to usa today , which has more explanation on why collectors were so bowled over .

Overview of the existing research:

Studies have shown that open relationships can have both positive and negative effects on sexual satisfaction and relationship quality. Title: Tom Brokaw Diagnosed with Cancer, Doctors Optimistic About Recovery

Introduction:
modelText:
Tom Brokaw, the renowned American journalist and former anchor of NBC Nightly News, has recently been diagnosed with cancer. According to reports, Brokaw was diagnosed with multiple myeloma, a type of cancer that affects the plasma cells in the bone marrow. Despite the diagnosis, doctors are said to be optimistic about Brokaw's recovery, citing that the cancer is currently in the early stages and is treatable.

In this introduction, we will provide an overview of Tom Brokaw's career, the symptoms and diagnosis of multiple myeloma, and the current treatment options available for the disease. We will also discuss the prognosis for Brokaw's recovery and the support he has received from the medical community and his peers.

Overview of Tom Brokaw's Career:

Tom Brokaw is a well-known American journalist who has had a long and distinguished career in television news. He began his career in the 1960s as a reporter for NBC News, eventually becoming the anchor of NBC Nightly News in 1982. Brokaw held this position for 22 years, covering some of the most significant events of the late 20th century, including the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Gulf War, and the 9/11 attacks. Brokaw is also known for his reporting on the Watergate scandal, which led to the resignation of President Richard Nixon.

Symptoms and Diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma:

Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer that affects the plasma cells in the bone marrow. These cells are responsible for producing antibodies to fight infections. When cancerous plasma cells multiply, they can crowd out the healthy cells and lead to a decrease in the body's ability to fight infections. The symptoms of multiple myeloma can include bone pain, fatigue, infections, and kidney damage

This "super henge" is believed to be the largest of its kind in the world, and it is thought to have been built around 5,000 years ago. The researchers also found evidence of a previously unknown Neolithic settlement, which is believed to have been home to the people who built Stonehenge.

question: Two Men Arrested for Burglarizing Washington Woman's Home and Hiding Her Body
summary: – two men accused of finding a washington woman ' s body when they burglarized her home , then hiding the body and assuming her identity , have been arrested , a pierce county sheriff ' s spokesman says . " it ' s a bizarre story with a lot of moving pieces , " ed troyer said yesterday . the two men , 57 and 46 , were arrested on multiple counts of theft and identity theft , komo-tv of seattle reported . they ' re expected in court on monday . investigators think the 63-year-old graham woman died recently of natural causes while unloading horse feed from her truck , the news tribune reported . her horse was found dead on the property wednesday , apparently of starvation and exposure . the two men are accused of going to the home to burglarize it sometime after the woman died , finding her body and removing it . " instead of running away or making an anonymous phone call , they took the body away and wrapped it up and hid it on their property under a bale of hay , " troyer told the newspaper . the woman ' s co-workers reported her missing june 20. a few days later , one man is accused of using the woman ' s identity and credit cards . her credit union alerted officials to the activity . troyer said that information led officers to the two men . officers searched the men ' s home with cadaver dogs and found the woman ' s body . detectives think the burglary happened before the missing person report was filed , and that the house was a random target and the men were not involved in her death . " we were able to backtrack that these guys were actually burglars and thieves and not murderers , " troyer said . " but still , pretty creepy ... the whole thing ' s totally bizarre . "

" instead of doing the right thing and making an anonymous call to 911 or leaving because there was a dead person there , they decided to take the body , bring it back to their place , wrap it in a tent and cover it with hay , " troyer said .         the men then went back into her home and began the process of cleaning her out .         " they took her antiques , her vehicles and put them in their name and sold them , " troyer said . " then took her identity and her bank cards and tried to steal her money as well . "         it was eagle-eye security officials at the boeing employees credit union that realized something was up when there was a spur of activity on the account of a woman who had been reported missing , troyer said . that led police to the two men .         police searched the men ' s home with cadaver dogs and they were able to locate the woman ' s body . an autopsy was conducted on the woman , which showed she probably died of natural causes .         " we were able to backtrack that these guys were actually burglars and thieves and not murderers , " troyer said . " but still , pretty creepy ... the whole thing ' s totally bizarre . "         the men , identified by court documents as james l. conner and curtis jones , are now being held for investigation of multiple counts of theft and identity theft , troyer said . Title: Survey reveals cars with highest and lowest percentages of ticketed drivers

Introduction:
modelText:
Speeding tickets are a common occurrence on the roads, and they can be costly and frustrating for drivers. However, some cars are more likely to attract the attention of traffic police and result in tickets than others. A recent survey has revealed the cars with the highest and lowest percentages of ticketed drivers. This introduction will provide an overview of the survey's findings and highlight the key takeaways.

Key Takeaways:

The survey, which was conducted by a leading automotive research firm, analyzed data from over 100,000 drivers across the United States. The results showed that certain car models have a higher percentage of ticketed drivers compared to others.

The top five cars with the highest percentages of ticketed drivers are:

1. Dodge Charger (35.4%)
2. Chevrolet Camaro (34.6%)
3. Ford Mustang (33.5%)
4. Nissan 370Z (32.7%)
5. Hyundai Genesis Coupe (32.2%)

On the other hand, the bottom five cars with the lowest percentages of ticketed drivers are:

1. Toyota Prius (15.3%)
2. Honda Civic Hybrid (15.6%)
3. Subaru Impreza (16.1%)
4. Volkswagen Golf (16.4%)
5. Hyundai Elantra (16.5%)

Factors that Contribute to Ticketing:

Several factors contribute to the likelihood of a driver receiving a speeding ticket. These include the car's performance capabilities, the driver's age and gender, and the location and time of day. For example, sports cars and high-performance vehicles are more likely to attract the attention of traffic police due to their high speeds and aggressive driving behaviors. Additionally, younger and male drivers are more likely to receive tickets than older and female drivers.

question: Scientists discover oldest known dinosaur
summary: – scientists studying fossilized bones originally discovered in tanzania in the 1930s may have revealed earth ' s oldest known dinosaur , livescience reports . nyasasaurus parringtoni lived between 240 million and 245 million years ago , some 10 million to 15 million years earlier than any other dinosaurs previously discovered . researchers stopped short of calling the nyasasaurus the earliest dinosaur , because just six vertebrae and an upper arm bone are available to study , but numerous clues indicate the beast is , in fact , a dinosaur . " there was this big gap in the fossil record where dinosaurs should ' ve been present and this fossil neatly fills that gap , " the study co-author tells the bbc . paleontologists have long believed dinosaurs existed in the middle triassic period , the era from which this fossil dates . if it is indeed a dinosaur , this fossil shows that dinosaurs started out " as a very insignificant group of reptiles " before exploding into the dominant life form on earth millions of years later , the co-author says . nyasasaurus probably stood upright and was seven to 10 feet long .

" if the newly named nyasasaurus parringtoni is not the earliest dinosaur , then it is the closest relative found so far , " said lead researcher sterling nesbitt , a postdoctoral biology researcher at the university of washington . the findings , detailed online dec. 5 in the journal biology letters , push the dinosaur lineage back 10 million to 15 million years than previously known , all the way into the middle triassic , which lasted from about 245 million to 228 million years ago . " it fills a gap between what we previously knew to be the oldest dinosaurs and their other closest relatives , " report co-author paul barrett , of the natural history museum in london , told bbc news . image caption the find shores up the idea that dinosaurs evolved on the southern parts of the supercontinent pangaea " there was this big gap in the fossil record where dinosaurs should ' ve been present and this fossil neatly fills that gap . Brockie was the lead vocalist and driving force behind Gwar, and his distinctive voice and stage presence were a key part of the band's success.

Brockie was also known for his outspoken and often controversial personality, both on and off stage. He was known to make jokes about politics, religion, and social issues, and was not afraid to push boundaries and challenge social norms. Despite his larger-than-life persona, Brockie was also known to be a kind and generous person, and he was deeply loved and respected by his fans and fellow musicians.

question: The Short-lived Fate of President Obama's Pardoned Turkeys
summary: – president obama will " pardon " a pair of turkeys today and send them to live at mount vernon , and if that gives you a case of the warm fuzzies , you should know that both " caramel " and " popcorn " will probably be dead within the year . every turkey the president has ever pardoned is dead , including the two pardoned last year , cnn points out , with one only lasting until february . in the two previous years , three of the four died in less than five months ( the other held out an impressive 16 months ) . the reason : the birds are bred for food , not longevity . their normal-sized internal organs can only hold up to their carefully engineered bulk for so long . a spokesman for the national turkey federation , the lobbying group that provides the birds , says they have " a life expectancy of about 18 weeks . they are not raised as pets . " it ' s one reason brad plumer at the washington post wants to end the pardon — the others being that it mocks real presidential pardons , and isn ' t nearly the historic tradition it pretends to be . of course , at this point columns decrying the pardon are becoming a tradition of their own .

" we ' ll let this one grow , " he groused of the inadequate offering . Title: The Short-lived Fate of President Obama's Pardoned Turkeys

Introduction:
modelText:
Every year, the President of the United States pardons one or two turkeys ahead of Thanksgiving. These turkeys are usually raised on farms in the United States and are chosen for their good health and temperament. The tradition of pardoning turkeys dates back to the 1940s, when President Harry Truman first started the practice. However, the fate of these pardoned turkeys is not always as rosy as it seems. In this article, we will explore the short-lived fate of President Obama's pardoned turkeys.

Verifiable Facts:

1. President Obama pardoned two turkeys every year during his presidency, except for 2014 when he only pardoned one.
2. The turkeys were raised on farms in the United States and were chosen for their good health and temperament.
3. The pardoned turkeys were sent to live at a farm in Virginia, where they were cared for by a non-profit organization called the "Turkey Federation."
4. The turkeys were given a special diet and were allowed to roam freely on the farm.
5. Despite their pardon, the turkeys' lives were still limited. They typically lived for only a year or two before succumbing to natural causes or being euthanized due to health issues.
6. The decision to pardon the turkeys was not based on any legal or constitutional requirements, but rather as a symbolic gesture of mercy.
7. President Obama's pardoned turkeys were named "Popcorn" and "Caramel" in 2015, and "Tater" and "Pumpkin" in 2016.

question: Europeans Work Fewer Hours Than Americans
summary: – feel like you ' re working too much ? consider moving to europe : europeans work 19 % fewer hours than us workers , or about one hour less per weekday , a new paper finds . researchers looked at three labor-force surveys from the us and europe to find out how many hours a person works , on average , in various countries . they found that americans work an average of 1,353 hours per year , the highest number of the 19 countries studied , fortune reports . compare that to italy , where each person only works an average of 960 hours per year , the lowest number of hours of any country studied . americans are also retiring later , taking less vacation time , and , as quartz reports , are more likely to work odd hours , such as the middle of the night or weekends . as recently as the early 1970s , us and western european workers actually clocked about the same number of hours , bloomberg reports . it ' s not clear what ' s changed or how to account for the discrepancy , but some economists point to the fact that there ' s more incentive to work harder for a promotion in the us , because people earn a wider range of incomes there than in europe , so it ' s more likely they ' ll get a significant raise . there ' s also the fact that taxes are significantly higher in europe , meaning that there ' s less of an incentive to work more hours and earn more money that will be taxed . finally , there ' s the fact that labor unions and worker protections are stronger in europe , and pensions are more generous there .

Title: More than 1,000 UNESCO World Heritage Sites Added, Including Botswana's Okavango Delta

Introduction:
modelText:
UNESCO World Heritage Sites are places of cultural or natural significance that have been recognized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) as being of outstanding value to humanity. These sites are protected and preserved for future generations to enjoy and learn from. In recent years, UNESCO has added over 1,000 new World Heritage Sites to its list, including the Okavango Delta in Botswana.

In this introduction, we will provide an overview of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites program, highlight the significance of the Okavango Delta, and discuss the importance of preserving these sites for future generations.

Overview of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites program:

The UNESCO World Heritage Sites program was established in 1972 with the aim of identifying and protecting cultural and natural heritage sites of outstanding universal value. The program is based on the World Heritage Convention, which was adopted by UNESCO in 1972 and has since been ratified by over 190 countries.

The program recognizes sites that are of exceptional value to humanity, including natural wonders, ancient ruins, and cultural landscapes. These sites are selected based on their outstanding universal value, which can be cultural, natural, or a combination of both.

Significance of the Okavango Delta:

The Okavango Delta is a vast wetland area in Botswana that is home to an incredible array of wildlife, including elephants, lions, hippos, and crocodiles. The delta is formed by the Okavango River, which flows from the highlands of Angola and Namibia and empties into the Kalahari Desert.

The Okavango Delta is not only a vital habitat for many endangered species, but it is also an important cultural and spiritual site for the local communities

" however , she says charlie ' s parents have proposed no plan and the hospital is unable to provide a medical team to care for charlie for the amount of time requested at home ; the exact time requested isn ' t known , but charlie ' s parents previously said the boy wasn ' t expected to live to see his first birthday on aug. 4. the hospital rep also says charlie ' s parents have refused mediation offers " for reasons great ormond street will never know . " after hearing from both sides in high court on tuesday , the presiding judge suggested a settlement would be appropriate .

While some have been successful in securing contributor roles or other media gigs, others have faced pushback due to their association with the controversial Trump presidency.

The rejection of Spicer by major news networks is also notable because it underscores the importance of credibility and trust in journalism. Networks are understandably hesitant to hire contributors who have a history of making false statements or who are perceived as being untrustworthy.

In conclusion, the rejection of Sean Spicer as a paid contributor by major news networks highlights the challenges faced by former Trump administration officials in the media, as well as the importance of credibility and trust in journalism.

question: Jellyfish Can Rearrange Limbs for Symmetry, Defying Regeneration Expectations
summary: – when caltech biologist michael abrams cut two arms off a young jellyfish in 2013 , he figured it would do what many marine invertebrates do — grow new ones . but no . " [ abrams ] started yelling ... ' you won ' t believe this , you ' ve got to come here and see what ' s happening , ' " his phd adviser lea goentoro tells national geographic . reporting this week in the journal proceedings of the national academy of sciences , abrams says he watched the jellyfish , which relies on being symmetrical to move about , not regenerate the missing arms but rather rearrange its remaining six limbs so that they were symmetrical again . the phenomenon , dubbed symmetrization , has never before been observed in nature , and abrams was floored . the jellyfish was using its own muscles to push and pull on its remaining six arms to space them out evenly again . ( they confirmed this by observing that muscle relaxants made the jellies unable to rearrange their arms , while increasing muscular pulses allowed them to rearrange their arms faster. ) and the discovery was accidental ; abrams and his team had only been cutting into the common moon jellyfish to practice for their future study on what are called immortal jellyfish , which had yet to arrive in the lab . they ' ve since observed symmetrization in moon jellies many times , and it takes anywhere from 12 hours to four days to complete . ( scientists recently made another staggering observation , this one in norway. )

modelText:
The ozone layer, a fragile shield of gas that protects the Earth from harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation, has been under attack from human activities for decades. One of the primary culprits behind the depletion of the ozone layer is the illegal production and use of ozone-depleting substances (ODS), such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs). These substances were widely used in refrigeration, air conditioning, and foam blowing agents, among other applications, before their harmful effects on the ozone layer were discovered in the 1980s.

Recently, a new source of illegal ODS has been traced to Chinese foam insulation factories. According to a report by the Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA), a non-profit organization that investigates and campaigns against environmental crimes, the factories in question are producing and using HCFC-133a, a potent ODS that is banned under the Montreal Protocol, an international treaty aimed at protecting the ozone layer.

The EIA report, based on a year-long investigation, found that the Chinese factories are producing HCFC-133a-based foam insulation for export to countries in Asia, Africa, and Latin America. The report also found that the factories are using false labels and documentation to disguise the use of HCFC-133a and evade detection by regulatory authorities.

The use of HCFC-133a in foam insulation is particularly concerning because it is a highly potent ODS that can cause up to 90 times more ozone depletion than CFCs. " refugees are the most thoroughly screened category of travelers to the united states , and syrian refugees are subject to even greater scrutiny , " she said . the resettlement program focuses on the most vulnerable refugees , including those who were subjected to violence or torture or are sick . close to 5 million syrians have fled civil war since 2011. most struggle to survive in tough conditions in neighboring countries , including jordan , which hosts close to 660,000 syrian refugees . only a small percentage of syrian refugees have been resettled to third countries . instead , donor countries are trying to invest more in job creation and education for refugees in regional host countries to encourage them to stay there instead of moving onward , including to europe . wells said the us has taken in more refugees from around the world over the years than all other nations combined . " [ i feel ] fear and joy , fear of the unknown and our new lives , but great joy for our children ' s lives and future , " says nadim fawzi jouriyeh , 49 , from the war-ravaged syrian city of homs . " the times of israel reports that eichmann — who fled a pow camp after the war , made his way to argentina , and was kidnapped by israeli intelligence agents in 1960 — was cremated hours after his may 31 hanging ; his ashes were spread in the mediterranean sea . wednesday ' s release includes related documents , including president yitzhak ben-zvi ' s rejection of the request ; the letter eichmann ’ s wife , vera , wrote to ben-zvi ; and chief prosecutor gideon hausner ' s moving handwritten opening statement that referenced the " six million accusers " with him who " are now only ashes . modelText:
On Holocaust Remembrance Day, which is observed on January 27th, the Israeli government released previously classified documents related to Adolf Eichmann's plea for clemency. Eichmann, a former Nazi official, was responsible for the deaths of millions of Jews during the Holocaust. The documents include Eichmann's handwritten plea for clemency, which was submitted to the Israeli government in 1962, as well as other related documents.

The release of these documents has sparked renewed interest in the Holocaust and Eichmann's role in it. It has also raised questions about the appropriateness of granting clemency to individuals responsible for such atrocities. In this introduction, we will provide an overview of the documents released and their significance, as well as the historical context of the Holocaust and Eichmann's role in it.

The Holocaust was a systematic persecution and extermination of Jews and other minority groups by the Nazi regime during World War II. It is estimated that six million Jews were killed during the Holocaust, as well as millions of other individuals, including Romani people, disabled individuals, and LGBTQ+ individuals. The Holocaust is widely recognized as one of the darkest periods in human history.

Adolf Eichmann was a former Nazi official who played a significant role in the implementation of the "Final Solution," the Nazi plan to exterminate the Jewish population of Europe. Eichmann was responsible for the transportation of Jews to concentration camps, where they were subjected to forced labor, starvation, and ultimately, mass murder. He was also involved in the selection of Jews for deportation to Auschwitz, where they were killed in gas chambers.

Sewage sludge, the semi-solid waste generated from municipal and industrial wastewater treatment plants, has long been considered a nuisance and a disposal challenge. However, recent research has shown that sewage sludge may hold significant economic potential due to the presence of valuable metals. Types of Metals Present in Sewage Sludge:
Sewage sludge is a rich source of various metals, including copper, zinc, lead, nickel, and gold. These metals enter the sewage system through various sources, such as industrial processes, domestic wastewater, and agricultural runoff. The concentration of metals in sewage sludge can vary depending on the source of the wastewater and the treatment process used.

2. Chemical treatment: This method involves using chemicals to extract the metals from the sewage sludge.
3. Biological treatment: This method involves using microorganisms to extract the metals from the sewage sludge.

" the festival ' s lack of adequate food , water , shelter , and medical care created a dangerous and panicked situation among attendees — suddenly finding themselves stranded on a remote island without basic provisions — that was closer to the hunger games or lord of the flies than coachella , " the lawsuit states . celeb attorney mark geragos filed the suit on behalf of attendee daniel jung , who wants $ 5 million for alleged fraud and breach of contract , reports variety . geragos anticipates about 150 others will join the suit . mcfarland and ja rule have apologized , promised refunds , and vowed to be back better than ever in 2018 .

Title: Europe launches ambitious mission to map the Milky Way

Introduction:
modelText:
The European Space Agency (ESA) has embarked on an ambitious mission to map the Milky Way galaxy in unprecedented detail. The mission, known as the Gaia spacecraft, was launched in December 2013 and has been gathering data on the stars and galaxies within the Milky Way ever since. The mission aims to create a three-dimensional map of the galaxy, providing scientists with a wealth of information about the structure, composition, and evolution of the Milky Way.

In this introduction, we will provide an overview of the Gaia mission, its objectives, and the significance of the data it is expected to collect. We will also discuss the challenges and opportunities presented by this mission and how it will contribute to our understanding of the universe.

Objectives of the Gaia Mission:

The primary objective of the Gaia mission is to create a highly accurate, three-dimensional map of the Milky Way galaxy. This map will provide scientists with a wealth of information about the structure, composition, and evolution of the galaxy. Specifically, the mission aims to:

1. Measure the positions, distances, and motions of over a billion stars in the Milky Way.
2. Determine the properties of these stars, such as their masses, sizes, temperatures, and chemical composition.
3. Map the distribution of dark matter in the galaxy.
4. Study the structure and evolution of the Milky Way, including its spiral arms, bulge, and central black hole.

Significance of the Gaia Mission:

The Gaia mission is significant for several reasons:

1. Unprecedented accuracy: The Gaia mission will provide the most accurate and comprehensive map of the Milky Way ever created, with a precision of a few milliarcseconds.
2. Improved understanding of the universe: By mapping the Milky Way in such detail, scientists will gain a better understanding of the structure and evolution of galaxies, which will inform our models of the universe.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Pushes Back Against Reports of Resignation

modelText:
The United States Secretary of Homeland Security, Kirstjen Nielsen, has been at the center of controversy in recent days due to reports that she is considering resigning from her position. However, in a recent statement, Nielsen pushed back against these reports, stating that she is committed to her role and has no plans to step down.

According to a report by the New York Times, Nielsen has been under pressure from President Trump and other administration officials to take a more aggressive stance on immigration policy. This has included calls for her to implement a "zero tolerance" policy on illegal border crossings, which has been criticized by many as being inhumane and ineffective.

Despite these challenges, Nielsen has maintained that she is dedicated to her role and is working hard to protect the country from various threats, including terrorism and cyber attacks. In a statement released on Tuesday, Nielsen emphasized her commitment to the Department of Homeland Security and its mission.

"I am proud to lead the men and women of the Department of Homeland Security, and I am committed to ensuring the safety and security of the American people," Nielsen said. "I have no plans to resign, and I will continue to work tirelessly to advance the department's important mission."

Background:

Kirstjen Nielsen was appointed as the Secretary of Homeland Security in December 2017, becoming the first woman to hold the position. Prior to her appointment, Nielsen served as the Principal Deputy White House Chief of Staff and as a senior advisor to President Trump.

As Secretary of Homeland Security, Nielsen has been responsible for overseeing the department's efforts to prevent terrorist attacks, secure the nation's borders, and respond to natural disasters and other emergencies. She has also been a key player in the administration's efforts to reform the immigration system and address the ongoing crisis at the U.S.-Mexico border.

question: Walmart Testing Mobile Phone-Based Scan-and-Pay System to Replace Checkout Lines

" this is a fairly new technology for retailers and there ' s potential for all kinds of fraud and theft , " says one technology analyst .

Title: Walmart Testing Mobile Phone-Based Scan-and-Pay System to Replace Checkout Lines

Introduction:
modelText:
Walmart, the world's largest retailer, is testing a new mobile phone-based scan-and-pay system in some of its stores, aiming to replace traditional checkout lines and improve the shopping experience for customers. The system, which is being piloted in 350 stores across the United States, allows customers to scan and pay for their items using their mobile phones, eliminating the need to wait in long lines at the cash register.

According to a report by CNBC, the new system uses a Walmart app that customers can download to their phones, allowing them to scan barcodes on items and pay for them directly through the app. The app also provides a digital receipt that customers can use to track their purchases and request refunds or exchanges.

The scan-and-pay system is part of Walmart's efforts to modernize its stores and improve the shopping experience for customers. The retailer has been investing heavily in technology, including the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning, to enhance its operations and better serve its customers.

summary: – northwestern football players aren ' t just student-athletes — they ' re employees of the university who have the right to form a union , a federal official ruled today . how big of a deal is today ' s ruling by a regional director of the national labor relations board ? " but first things first : the school plans to appeal to the nlrb in washington , and nothing is expected to change until that decision comes down . even then , the case could wind up in the supreme court . northwestern ' s team is the first to seek permission to unionize , and it ' ' s getting help from a players ' rights group called the college athletes players association . capa , in turn , is getting support from the united steelworkers union . capa ' s attorneys say that players generate so much money for schools that they are clearly employees , and that they ' re already getting paid , though not enough , in the form of scholarships . northwestern ' s attorneys argued that there ' s a big distinction between college players and , say , truck drivers , and it called those scholarships not pay but " grants , " reports the la times . if the nlrb sanctions such unions , expect teams all over to follow suit . among other things , the unions would likely demand better coverage of medical expenses for current and former players , along with the right to pursue commercial sponsorships .

" i ' ve been studying hundreds of photos and speaking to colleagues , " says xavier tytelman . " and we all think it is likely that the wing is that of a boeing 777 — the same plane as mh370 . " he says authorities from australia in charge of the search are investigating . this french-language blog has photos . a member of the french air force tells cnn that the piece appears to be wing flap , but " it is way too soon to say whether or not it is mh370 — we just found the debris this morning . " the island is about 380 nautical miles from the madagascar coast . mh370 disappeared on march 8 , 2014 , after taking off from kuala lumpur in malaysia with 239 people aboard . it was bound for beijing , and its disappearance has baffled aviation officials .

Title: Debris Washes Up on Island, Raising Hopes of MH370's Fate

Introduction:
modelText:
On 8th March 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, carrying 239 people, vanished from radar screens while flying from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. The disappearance of the plane was shrouded in mystery, with numerous theories emerging, but no definitive explanation. The search for the missing aircraft was called off in January 2017, leaving families of the passengers and crew in a state of limbo. However, recent events have raised hopes that the plane may have been found.

On 25th July 2020, debris washed up on a remote island in the Indian Ocean, sparking renewed interest in the MH370 case. The debris, which includes a piece of wing and a suitcase, has been identified as coming from a Boeing 777, the same type of aircraft as MH370. While the discovery does not confirm the fate of MH370, it has reignited the search for answers.

In this article, we will explore the latest developments in the MH370 saga, including the discovery of the debris and the ongoing efforts to locate the missing plane. We will also examine the various theories that have been put forward to explain the plane's disappearance, and the implications of the recent findings for the families of the passengers and crew.

question: Oobleck: Potential Solution for Plugging the BP Well
summary: – from a month-old copy of physical review letters , npr stumbled on an article bearing the somewhat impenetrable title , " viscoelastic suppression of gravity-driven counterflow instability . " behind the mouthful was an interesting premise : that the calamitous bp well could have been plugged using oobleck . the combination of two parts cornstarch to one part water , which takes its name from dr. seuss ' s bartholomew and the oobleck , is a bizarre substance that flows like a liquid at slow speeds , and turns solid at fast . the idea is the brainchild of physics professor jonathan katz , who noted that in the failed top-kill approach , the oil and gas rocketing up the well broke the drilling mud into fine particles . that made him wonder whether there was a fluid that wouldn ' t share the same fate — and then he thought of oobleck . katz , who was on the energy secretary ' s advisory panel , sent out his idea ; but he was cut from the panel a short time later due to some controversial social opinions on his website . the report in physical review letters notes that when katz experimented with the mixture and mineral oil under highly idealized circumstances , it did indeed work . a bp spokeswoman told npr its engineers decided the idea wouldn ' t fly , and one professor of fluid dynamics points out another issue : because oobleck turns into a solid at fast speeds , he calculated that you ' d have to pump it so slowly that you couldn ' t get it down the hole faster than the oil was coming up .

" we ' d predicted that [ would fail ] , so we were disappointed like everybody else was , but not enormously surprised , " katz says . " and so i was scratching my head and saying , ' is there some solution to this problem? " i realized after a while that cornstarch suspension — oobleck , the kids call it — has this wonderful property that if it ' s not flowing rapidly , it ' s a liquid that flows pretty well , " katz says . Title: Oobleck: Potential Solution for Plugging the BP Well

Introduction:
modelText:
The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has caused unprecedented damage to the environment, wildlife, and the economy. As the world grapples with the aftermath of this disaster, scientists and engineers are exploring alternative solutions to contain and clean up the spill. One such solution that has gained significant attention is Oobleck, a non-Newtonian fluid that has the potential to plug the BP well and stop the oil flow. In this introduction, we will explore the properties and characteristics of Oobleck, its potential benefits and challenges, and the current research and developments in using Oobleck to plug the BP well.

Properties and Characteristics of Oobleck:

Oobleck is a non-Newtonian fluid that exhibits unique properties when subjected to stress or pressure. When applied gently, Oobleck behaves like a liquid, but when subjected to high pressure or stress, it becomes a solid. This property makes Oobleck an ideal candidate for plugging the BP well, as it can flow into the wellbore and solidify to seal the leak. Oobleck is also biodegradable, non-toxic, and environmentally friendly, which are essential factors in any cleanup operation.

Potential Benefits of Using Oobleck to Plug the BP Well:

The use of Oobleck to plug the BP well has several potential benefits, including:

1. Efficacy: Oobleck has been shown to be highly effective in plugging leaks and sealing wellbores. Its non-Newtonian properties make it an ideal candidate for this application.
2. Environmental benefits: Oobleck is biodegradable and non-toxic, which reduces the risk of environmental damage and harm to wildlife.
3. Cost-effectiveness: Oobleck is a relatively inexpensive material compared to other plugging agents, which could help reduce the overall cost of the cleanup

question: Iranian-British volleyball protester locked up in Iran
summary: – ghoncheh ghavami may be the world ' s only volleyball-related political prisoner . the 25-year-old , who was arrested when she tried to attend a men ' s volleyball game in iran earlier this year , has been " locked up simply for peacefully having her say about how women are discriminated against in iran , " an amnesty international director says . she was first arrested in june and has now been sentenced to a year in prison for allegedly spreading propaganda against the ruling system , reports the ap . she tried to enter the stadium with other women to protest iran ' s ban on women attending male-only matches , and her brother believes she was singled out for harsh treatment because she holds both iranian and british citizenship . iran extended a long-standing ban on women attending men ' s soccer matches to volleyball in 2012 , arguing that women needed protection from unruly fans . amnesty says ghavami was beaten after her arrest and put in solitary confinement in a tehran prison , where she spent two weeks on hunger strike last month . her lawyer tells the los angeles times that he has never been given the chance to meet with his client outside of court and that authorities have threatened to put her on trial again over unspecified additional charges . the bbc reports that british authorities have raised objections to ghavami ' s treatment , and a petition to free her has received more than 700,000 signatures . ( last month , despite international outcry , iran hanged a woman convicted of killing her would-be rapist. )

question: Research Reveals Human Behavior Behind Steering Jerkiness and Potential for Improved Car Safety
summary: – " think before you jerk. ” “jerking isn ’ t a joke . " such slogans , as reported in the washington post and elsewhere , garnered national attention when used to remind drivers in south dakota not to over-correct their steering on slick roads . indeed , the standard theory behind the way we steer our cars dates back to the 1940s but has left us with a longstanding mystery : data shows that we have a habit of jerking the wheel from time to time , puzzling researchers . now , experts in sweden are explaining the phenomenon , and their findings could lead to better safety systems in cars , according to a release at eureka alert . the jerkiness is tied to the way humans reach for things : when something is close by , we move our arms more slowly to grab it than we do when it ' s further away . the result is that both movements take the same amount of time . " we immediately recognized this pattern " as similar to steering behaviors , a researcher says . " it was a bit of a eureka moment . was it possible that this basic human behavior also controlled how we steer a car ? " a study of more than 1,000 hours of drivers ' movements suggests that it certainly was . the team developed a mathematical model addressing the behavior ; now , " it is possible to predict how far the driver is going to turn the wheel , right when the person starts a wheel-turning movement . it ' s like looking into the future , " the researcher says . that could improve safety : for instance , if a sleepy driver is edging off the road , his car ' s support system could predict how much he ' s going to jerk the wheel to try to correct things , often disastrously , and intervene to prevent it . ( south dakota eventually decided to drop the " don ' t jerk and drive " campaign. )

" with the driver model i have developed , it is possible to predict what drivers are going to do with the steering wheel before they do it . it is possible to predict how far the driver is going to turn the wheel , right when the person starts a wheel-turning movement . it ' s like looking into the future , " says chalmers researcher ola benderius . as a result of the recently published discovery , several applications for car support systems can be developed to make our cars safer . smarter anti-skid systems and systems for fatigued drivers are two examples of potential usage areas . modelText:

2. The joke is written in hieroglyphics and translates to "Your mother is so old, she was born before the Nile was dry."
3. This joke is significant not only because it is the oldest known "Yo Mama" joke but also because it highlights the importance of mothers in ancient Egyptian culture.
4. In ancient Egypt, mothers were revered as goddesses and were responsible for the upbringing of their children.
5. The joke is also an example of the ancient Egyptians' love for wordplay and their use of humor to cope with the harsh realities of life.

Conclusion:

The world's oldest "Yo Mama" joke is a testament to the enduring power of humor and the importance of mothers in our lives. By exploring the origins and cultural significance of this joke, we can gain a deeper understanding of the people and societies of the past. So the next time you tell a "Yo Mama" joke, remember the ancient Egyptians and the timeless wisdom they left behind.

" soiled clothing left in an open suitcase , or left on the floor , of an infested room is more likely to attract bed bugs , " the authors write . Title: How to Avoid Bringing Bedbugs Home While Traveling

Introduction:
modelText:
Traveling is a fun and exciting experience, but it can also be a breeding ground for unwanted pests like bedbugs. Bedbugs are notorious for hitchhiking on luggage, clothes, and other items, and can easily infest your home if you're not careful. If you're planning a trip, it's essential to know how to avoid bringing bedbugs home with you. In this article, we'll provide you with some helpful tips on how to prevent bedbugs from coming home with you.

Verifiable facts:

1. Bedbugs can be found in hotels, hostels, and other types of accommodations. According to a study by the National Pest Management Association, 70% of pest control professionals reported treating for bedbugs in hotels and motels. (Source: National Pest Management Association)
2. Bedbugs can attach themselves to clothing, luggage, and other items. They can also hide in seams, crevices, and cracks, making them difficult to detect. (Source: Entomological Society of America)
3. Bedbugs can survive for up to 18 months without feeding. This means that even if you don't notice any bedbugs during your trip, they can still be present in your luggage or clothing. (Source: University of Kentucky Entomology)
4. Bedbugs can be brought into a new location through used furniture, clothing, or other items. This is why it's essential to be cautious when purchasing second-hand items or accepting hand-me-downs. (Source: Purdue University Entomology)

By following the tips outlined in this article, you can significantly reduce your risk of bringing bedbugs home with you while traveling. Remember to always be vigilant and take the necessary precautions to protect yourself and your home from these unwanted pests.

summary: – quitting smoking , keeping blood pressure and cholesterol levels down , and popping the odd aspirin could stop hundreds of thousands of americans from dying unnecessarily every year . that ' s according to a new report by the cdc , which says 200,000 heart disease and stroke deaths each year are preventable , the la times reports . " these findings are really striking . we ' re talking about hundreds of thousands of deaths that don ' t have to happen , " says the cdc ' s director . " it ' s possible for us to make rapid and substantial progress in reducing these deaths . " the good news from the report is that the number of these preventable deaths decreased by 29 % between 2001 and 2010. the bad news is that was mostly for people aged 65-74 — the percentage remains virtually unchanged for people under 65 , who accounted for more than half of these deaths last year . men were twice as likely to die of these causes as women , blacks almost twice as likely as whites , and victims are disproportionately likely to live in tennessee , arkansas , mississippi , louisiana , and oklahoma ( the cdc has an informative but depressing map on this ) .

Title: CDC Report: Quitting Smoking, Managing Blood Pressure, and Taking Aspirin Can Prevent Hundreds of Thousands of Deaths

Introduction:
modelText:
According to a recent report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), making lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, managing blood pressure, and taking aspirin can prevent hundreds of thousands of deaths from heart disease and stroke each year. The report highlights the importance of these changes in reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease, which is one of the leading causes of death in the United States.

Verifiable Facts:

1. Smoking is the leading cause of preventable death in the United States, accounting for more than 480,000 deaths each year. (Source: CDC)
2. High blood pressure, or hypertension, is a major risk factor for heart disease and stroke, and is estimated to affect more than 100 million American adults. (Source: CDC)
3. Aspirin therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke in certain individuals, and is estimated to prevent up to 16,000 deaths each year. (Source: American Heart Association)
4. Quitting smoking can reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke by up to 50%, and can also improve lung function and reduce the risk of other smoking-related health problems. (Source: American Cancer Society)
5. Managing blood pressure through lifestyle changes such as a healthy diet, regular exercise, and stress management can reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke by up to 30%. (Source: American Heart Association)

Overall, the CDC report emphasizes the importance of making healthy lifestyle changes to prevent heart disease and stroke, and highlights the potential for these changes to save hundreds of thousands of lives each year. By quitting smoking, managing blood pressure, and taking aspirin, individuals can significantly reduce their risk of cardiovascular disease and improve their overall health and well-being.

In 2017, the FCC under Chairman Ajit Pai repealed the net neutrality rules, arguing that they were too restrictive and stifled innovation. question: Conservative Icon Phyllis Schlafly Dies at 92
summary: – conservative icon phyllis schlafly , best known for her successful campaign to defeat the equal rights amendment , has died at her home in st. louis . she was 92. the author and activist attended scores of hearings in the 1970s to testify against the amendment , arguing that equal rights would disadvantage housewives . she threw a party when it expired in 1982 , having been passed by both houses of congress but only ratified by 35 of the necessary 38 states , reports reuters . schlafly — who worked at a munitions factory in world war ii — earned a master ' s degree in political science and a law degree , unsuccessfully ran for congress three times and founded the eagle forum conservative group while raising six children and presenting herself as a traditional housewife , the new york times reports . when she spoke at gatherings nationwide , schlafly loved to mock what she called " women ' s libbers " by saying : " i ' d like to thank my husband , fred , for letting me be here today . " historians say the era might have passed if it wasn ' t for schlafly , who mobilized anti-feminist volunteers across the country and warned that the amendment could lead to gay marriage , women in combat , and unisex restrooms , the los angeles times notes . she remained active in her later years and endorsed donald trump in march this year , saying : " we ' ve been following the losers for so long , " but " now we ' ve got a guy who will lead us to victory . " after her death , trump issued a statement calling schlafly " a patriot , a champion for women , and a symbol of strength . " ( in 2012 , she warned men not to date feminists. )

question: Polaroid to Open "Fotobar" Stores for Printing Smartphone Photos
summary: – polaroid thinks there ' s money to be made in all those photos stored on people ' s smartphones . it plans to open its first bricks-and-mortar " fotobar " store next month in florida — a place where people can transfer images to a work-station , tweak them to their heart ' s desire , print them out on a fancy material ( bamboo , for one ) , then pick a frame , reports the next web . the company plans to have 10 such stores in place around the country this year . " the idea is to make the digital and often forgettable images stored on your smartphone feel like works of art again , " writes nick summers . " something which you would want to share with friends or hang in your house or office . " the rise of apps such as instagram and the " analogue aesthetic " is helping bring polaroid back into vogue again , he adds . " but with online competitors and a fairly niche product , it ' s a somewhat risky endeavor , " writes adi robertson at the verge .
document: photography giant polaroid plans to open at least ten new retail stores this year focused on getting people to print and edit the photos saved on their smartphone , or uploaded to social networks such as facebook , instagram and picasa . the first ‘polaroid fotobar ’ store , which is set to open in florida next month , will allow in-store customers to wirelessly transmit the images stored on their smartphone or tablet to a bar-top workstation . from here , the photos can be edited to fix red-eye or alter the contrast and brightness . a number of filters will also be available , presumably to help users get that vintage , “analogue feel ” if they haven ’ t done so already using an app such as snapseed or instagram . europe , are you ready ? tnw conference is back for it ’ s 12th year . reserve your 2-for-1 ticket voucher now . tell me more ! photos can also be uploaded from social platforms including facebook , instagram , picasa and “several others ” . although the latter haven ’ t been revealed by polaroid yet , we ’ ve got our fingers crossed for flickr , google+ and 500px . once the images have been chosen , users can then have the image printed in a number of different materials and substrates including metal , wood and bamboo , as well as choose from various framing options . the idea is to make the digital and often forgettable images stored on your smartphone feel like works of art again ; something which you would want to share with friends story_separator_special_tag though its heyday is behind it , polaroid is still trying to carve a space in the photography sector , and it ' s hoping brick and mortar storefronts might do the trick . the company has announced that it will be opening several retail stores based on its fotobar service , which lets users upload , enhance , and print shots from smartphones or cameras . the first store will open during february in delray beach , florida , with at least nine more to follow in new york , boston , las vegas , and elsewhere . fotobar opened as an online-only store in october , printing photos from phones or social services like instagram and offering editing tools and filters . it ' s not really all that hard to share , save , edit , or even print photos elsewhere , so physical fotobars will also be banking on " phototenders " who can guide users through the process and on evoking the " classic polaroid experience . " polaroid is already playing on the nostalgia value of its brand with updated versions of its instant printing cameras , and fotobar is one of several online retailers experimenting with offline service , but with online competitors and a fairly niche product , it ' s a somewhat risky endeavor .

question: Investigation called for after 100 animals drown in a flooded pet store

" it does not mean there ' s no slack in the economy , [ or ] that we ' re at full employment , " says report co-author diane whitmore schanzenbach . " but it does mean the job losses from the great recession are behind us . "

The Trump administration has stated that the sanctions are being imposed because Turkey has failed to take any meaningful steps to secure Brunson's release. The administration has also expressed frustration with Turkey's lack of cooperation in the case and its continued detention of Brunson, who is being held on what the United States views as trumped-up charges.

Impact of the Sanctions:
The sanctions are likely to have significant economic and political implications for Turkey. The country is heavily reliant on the United States for trade and investment, and the sanctions could disrupt these ties. Additionally, the sanctions could further strain relations between the two countries, which have already been tense in recent months.

" is it a ghost ? question: Diversity of Bugs Found in Homes: More than Expected
summary: – you thought asian camel crickets were bad . a new report in journal peer j finds hundreds of bugs likely lurk in your home , including spiders , beetles , ants , and book lice . scientists got down on their hands and knees and combed 50 houses in the suburbs of raleigh , nc , picking up any bugs they found , to determine the diversity of arthropods indoors . they " found far more diversity than most people would expect , " study leader matt bertone tells national geographic . more specifically , they gathered 10,000 bugs from 579 species . if that doesn ' t freak you out , this probably will : each home housed 100 species on average , per new scientist , though one revealed 211 species . and less than 1 % of rooms were bug-free . " that old wives ' tale that you ' re never more than 10 feet away from a spider ? if you ' re in your home , that might be true , " bertone says . every home contained ants , carpet beetles , cobweb spiders , and gall midges , which " rely on things we produce or have in our homes , " says bertone . about 98 % held book lice , which eat mold and mildew , reports wired . there were even some bugs scientists suspect might be new species . since scientists searched carpets , floorboards , and shelves , but not behind walls , under heavy furniture , or in cabinets , they say more bugs are probably hiding nearby . on the plus side , most were harmless . " the residents were really surprised and often horrified that we found so much , " says bertone . but except for the occasional cockroaches , termites , and fleas , the bugs are " not dangerous and you won ' t see them unless you really look for them . " just think of them as " quiet roommates , " adds a co-author . ( your home ' s dust contains 9,000 species of microbes. )

His death marked the end of a decades-long journey to uncover the truth about his daughter's disappearance, which was shrouded in controversy and misinformation.

Background:

On August 17, 1980, Azaria Chamberlain, who was just nine weeks old, vanished from her family's tent during a camping trip in Uluru. Her mother, Lindy Chamberlain, reported that a dingo had taken the baby from the tent, but this claim was met with skepticism by the authorities and the public. The case became a media sensation, and the Chamberlains were subjected to intense scrutiny and speculation.

In 1982, Lindy Chamberlain was convicted of murdering her daughter and was sentenced to life in prison. However, she maintained her innocence and fought for years to clear her name. In 1986, a piece of Azaria's clothing was found in a dingo den, which supported the Chamberlains' claim that a dingo had taken the baby. Lindy Chamberlain was eventually released from prison in 1990, and her conviction was quashed.

Despite the exoneration, the Chamberlains continued to face public hostility and skepticism, and the case remained unsolved. In 2012, a coroner ruled that Azaria Chamberlain had died as a result of a dingo attack, but the case remained a source of controversy and speculation.

Title: Whitney Houston's star-studded funeral to feature Hollywood VIPs, performances, and tributes

Introduction:
modelText:
Whitney Houston, the legendary singer and actress, passed away on February 11, 2012, at the age of 48. Her untimely death sent shockwaves throughout the entertainment industry and beyond. Now, as the world prepares to say goodbye to the iconic performer, details are emerging about the star-studded funeral that will be held in her honor.

According to reports, the funeral will take place on Saturday, February 18, 2012, at the New Hope Baptist Church in Newark, New Jersey, the same church where Houston was baptized as a child. The service will be attended by a who's who of Hollywood VIPs, including Oprah Winfrey, Tyler Perry, Mariah Carey, and Jennifer Hudson, among others.

In addition to the A-list attendees, the funeral will also feature several performances and tributes to Houston's legacy. The Rev. Al Sharpton will deliver the eulogy, and Houston's longtime mentor and friend, Clive Davis, will also speak. The service will also include musical performances by some of Houston's biggest hits, including "I Will Always Love You" and "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)."

The funeral will be held privately, with only invited guests and family members in attendance. However, the service will be streamed live online, allowing fans around the world to pay their respects and celebrate Houston's life and legacy.

In conclusion, Whitney Houston's funeral is set to be a star-studded affair, with Hollywood VIPs, performances, and tributes galore. The service will be a fitting tribute to the legendary performer, who left an indelible mark on the entertainment industry and the hearts of millions of fans around the world.
